gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: counter_13. 

Explanation: This is a 13-bit counter module. It increments the counter "count" every positive edge of the clock when the "enable" input signal is high. It resets the counter to zero when the "reset" input signal is high, regardless of the clock or "enable" signal values.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input Ports: clock, enable, reset. 

Explanation: "clock" acts as the source of timing events that guide the sequential operation of the counter. "enable" acts as a control signal that, when high, allows the counter to increment upon the positive edge of clock. "reset" is another control signal used to reset the count value to zero when it is high, irrespective of the state of the clock or the 'enable' signal.

Output Ports: count.

Explanation: "count" is the output port that provides the current value of the 13-bit counter. This value increments with each clock cycle when the 'enable' signal is high and resets to zero when the 'reset' signal is high.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: count.

Explanation: "count" is the only internal signal in the counter_13 module. It is a register that stores the value of the 13-bit counter. This internal signal increments by 1 at every positive edge of the clock when the "enable" signal is high. If the "reset" signal is high, it becomes zero irrespective of the clock and enable signals.
